DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Activates Media Pool for Panama Operation
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Defense activated a news media pool that arrived in Panama today alongside U.S. troops dispatched by President Bush. The pool was developed after the controversy over secrecy surrounding the 1982 American military operation in Grenada. ``The purpose of the pool is to be there at the beginning of the operation,'' said a Pentagon official, who spoke on condition that he not be further identified. He said Pentagon pools are usually disbanded after the first several days as other reporters arrive on the scene. Notifying and assembling the pool takes place under terms of secrecy that are unusual for the press. The Pentagon requires that pool members not tell others about their assignment. ``We ask them to tell their families that they have been called to work. That is not that unusual late at night for journalists. We ask them not to have their spouses drive them to Andrews Air Force Base, but to drive themselves or find some other way of getting there,'' said the Pentagon source. The Pentagon pool in Panama is made up of journalists from the following news organizations: The Associated Press; United Press International; Reuters; Time Magazine; ABC Radio; NBC Television; Houston Chronicle; Houston Post, and Dallas Morning News. The initial writer's report was received at midmorning Wednesday, but news organizations were still waiting for photography from the pool well after noon. News executives receive short notice when a pool is being activated and assign the staff members who provide coverage. Their material is made available to other media organizations that do not take part. Participation in the pool is rotated several times a year. News executives notified that the pool has been activated are also sworn to secrecy. The first pool was formed in April 1985, and they have been assembled on average of twice a year since then, officials said. One pool accompanied U.S. Navy warships escorting oil tankers through the Persian Gulf in July 1987, but most times reporters receiving the midnight summons have watched military maneuvers. The most recent previous pool also went to Panama, in May 1989, a 12-member group that accompanied the first extra detachment of Marines sent there in Operation Nimrod Dancer. That pool was not kept secret, because President Bush announced the operation earlier in the day.
